AvProblem.comment: above the timberline, behind discontinuities, in gullies, steep bowls

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is moderate above 1800 m, below that altitude danger is low. Fresh trigger-prone snowdrifts are the main danger. Danger zones occur on N/E/S facing slopes at entries to steep gullies and bowls and in general behind discontinuities in the terrain where fresh snowdrifts can trigger a medium slab avalanche by 1 person down to the treeline, releases up to medium size. Frequency and size of danger zones increase with ascending altitude. As a result of solar radiation, isolated small loose-snow slides are possible in extremely steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow (30-50 cm) of the last few days lies deposited atop a compact snowpack base. The old snow is thoroughly moist, but was able to consolidate due to the lower temperatures in recent days. The fresh snow is well bonded with the old snowpack. Further snowfall plus brisk W/NW winds will generate fresh small snowdrift accumulations, bonding to the loose fresh fallen snow is poor, prone to triggering. As a result of solar radiation, the fresh snow will be able to settle during the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Gray skies in the northern barrier clouds regions on Sunday, minor snowfall compared to the last few days. Further south, sunny intervals, brisk-to-strong N/NW winds, also snow showers as an exception. Winds will slacken off. At 2000 m: -8 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: It will remain cool, but mostly dry. Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

AvProblem.comment: small, thin snowdrift patches, ridgeline snowdrift patches, behind discontinuities

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger only isolated danger zones
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is generally low. Older snowdrifts at high altitudes can trigger small slab avalanches in isolated cases. Danger zones occur near ridges, at entries into steep gullies and bowls and behind discontinuities in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On what was previously bare ground or atop a moist compact old snowpack the fresh snow and drifts from the beginning of the week lie deposited, well bonded with the snowpack and already settled. Thin snowdrift patches will be generated by brisk winds. Weak layer: loose layers in the fresh drifts or blanked fresh snow from the beginning of the week.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Gray skies in the northern barrier clouds regions on Sunday, minor snowfall compared to the last few days. Further south, sunny intervals, brisk-to-strong N/NW winds, also snow showers as an exception. Winds will slacken off. At 2000 m: -8 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: It will remain cool, but mostly dry. Avalanche danger levels remain low.

AvProblem.comment: behind discontinuities, in gullies, steep bowls, near the treeline
loose-snow avalanches in extremely steep terrain

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is considerable above 1800 m, below that altitude danger is low. Fresh trigger-prone snowdrifts are the main danger. Danger zones occur on N/E/SW facing slopes at entries to steep gullies and bowls and in general behind discontinuities in the terrain where fresh snowdrifts can trigger a medium slab avalanche by 1 person down to the treeline, releases up to medium size. Frequency and size of danger zones increase with ascending altitude. In case of sunny intervals, small loose-snow avalanches can trigger naturally in extremely steep terrain. In places, loose-snow avalanches can be triggered by 1 person.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow (70-100 cm) of the last few days lies deposited atop a compact snowpack base. The old snow is thoroughly moist, but was able to consolidate due to the lower temperatures in recent days. The fresh snow is well bonded with the old snowpack. Further snowfall plus brisk W/NW winds will generate fresh small snowdrift accumulations, bonding to the loose fresh fallen snow will be poor, bringing a weak layer for slab avalanches. Solar radiation will help the fresh fallen snow to settle.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Gray skies in the northern barrier clouds regions on Sunday, minor snowfall compared to the last few days. Further south, sunny intervals, brisk-to-strong N/NW winds, also snow showers as an exception. Winds will slacken off. At 2000 m: -8 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: It will remain cool, but mostly dry except along the northern flank of the Alps. Avalanche danger levels will recede.
